title: David Anointed King
shortSummary: In 1 Samuel 16, God directs Samuel to anoint David, the youngest son of Jesse, as the future king of Israel, replacing Saul. This chapter highlights God's sovereign choice based on the heart rather than outward appearance and introduces David’s role as Saul’s harp player to soothe the troubled king.
timeline: c. 1050 BC - The anointing of David as future king during the period of the early monarchy in Israel

keyCharacters.name: Samuel
keyCharacters.description: The prophet and judge who is obedient to God's command to anoint a new king for Israel.

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: The youngest son of Jesse, chosen by God for kingship and anointed by Samuel; he later serves Saul as a harp player.

keyCharacters.name: Saul
keyCharacters.description: The first king of Israel, rejected by God, whose spirit departs and who is troubled by an evil spirit.

keyCharacters.name: Jesse
keyCharacters.description: A Bethlehemite and father of David, who presents his sons to Samuel for God's selection.

definitions.definition: A container made from an animal horn used to hold oil for anointing kings or priests, symbolizing God's empowerment.
To pour oil on someone as a sign of consecration and divine appointment to a special role or office.
A troubling spirit sent by God to discipline or test Saul, reflecting God's sovereign control over all spirits.
To set apart as holy or consecrated for a sacred purpose.

outline.heading: God Rejects Saul and Sends Samuel to Jesse
outline.description: God instructs Samuel to stop mourning Saul and to anoint a new king from Jesse’s sons, emphasizing God’s sovereign choice. Samuel obeys and goes to Bethlehem, preparing for the sacred anointing.

outline.heading: Samuel Anoints David as King
outline.description: Samuel evaluates Jesse’s sons but God rejects them based on their outward appearance, choosing David for his heart. Samuel anoints David, and the Spirit of the LORD comes upon him, marking divine approval and empowerment.

outline.heading: The Spirit Departs from Saul
outline.description: The Spirit of the LORD departs from Saul, and he is troubled by an evil spirit. Saul’s servants suggest finding a skilled harp player to soothe him, leading to David’s introduction into Saul’s service as his armor-bearer and musician.

application: Trust God’s sovereign choice rather than judging by outward appearances, seeking to cultivate a heart pleasing to Him.
Obey God’s instructions promptly, even when they involve difficult or risky actions, as Samuel did in anointing David.
Recognize God’s power to change circumstances and provide help in times of distress, as seen in David’s ministry to Saul.
Be willing to serve faithfully in small roles, trusting God to prepare and position you for greater purposes.

keyVerses.text: But the LORD said unto Samuel, Look not on his countenance, or on the height of his stature; because I have refused him: for the LORD seeth not as man seeth; for man looketh on the outward appearance, but the LORD looketh on the heart.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God’s criteria for leadership and selection, emphasizing the importance of the heart over external appearance.

keyVerses.text: Then Samuel took the horn of oil, and anointed him in the midst of his brethren: and the Spirit of the LORD came upon David from that day forward. So Samuel rose up, and went to Ramah.
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks the divine anointing of David and the empowering presence of the Holy Spirit for his future role as king.

keyVerses.text: And it came to pass, when the evil spirit from God was upon Saul, that David took an harp, and played with his hand: so Saul was refreshed, and was well, and the evil spirit departed from him.
keyVerses.significance: This verse illustrates God’s provision of comfort and relief through David’s musical ministry, demonstrating God’s care for Saul despite his rejection.
